questions.question_text: What is the purpose of ADOM revisions?

discussion.content:

Selected Answer: D

comments.content: Answer is D. Page 233 of the Study Guide says 'Create a snapshot of all policy and objects configurations for the ADOM' - not everything in the entire ADOM.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
An ADOM Revision is a snapshot of the entire ADOM
Page 227

choices.C: To save the current state of the whole ADOM
choices.B: To revert individual policy packages and device-level settings for a managed FortiGate
choices.D: To save the current state of all policy packages and objects for an ADOM
choices.A: To save the FortiManager configuration in the System Checkpoints

discussion.content: A&B are correct. The admins can lock one or more policies each and can work on the same ADOM! C is nonsense cuz nothing is disabled unless one admin has locked an ADOM!

Selected Answer: BC
B and C

Selected Answer: BC
B. 
Correct. In normal workspace mode, an administrator can lock multiple ADOMs or projects for editing simultaneously. This allows for flexibility in managing various parts of the network without being restricted to a single ADOM at a time.

C. 
Correct. This is in line with the idea of locking in workspace mode. While in normal mode, concurrent read-write access is indeed disabled, ensuring that only the administrator who has locked the ADOM can make changes. This prevents conflicts and overwrites in configurations.

Selected Answer: BC
B and C

Selected Answer: BC
B & C
A - wrong they do not refer to policy lock so is just workspace mode normal. Once a user locks the ADOM that particular ADOM appers with a red lock to any other user. I put that in a lab.
b - Correct the user can lock more than one ADOMs. Put that is a lab too
c - seems correct as that justifies to what I say for option A. 
d - doent make sense

Selected Answer: BC
I would say this is BC 

Question shows Workspace-mode normal - it's not stating policy locking is enabled, so i assume it is disabled.

A - With workspace mode you have to lock the ADOM, which prevents other admins from using the ADOM. -- Incorrect
B - An Admin can lock multiple ADOMs at the same time - Correct
C. Once workspace is enabled (not policy locking) and the Admin has locked an ADOM. Then no other Admins can make changes to that ADOM until it's been unlocked by the original Admin - Correct
D. Syslog servers can be enabled for event logs, but it's not what the questions looking for. So I'd say incorrect.

Selected Answer: AB
Ingore my previous answer, copy and past did not work...
7.4 study guide, pg 205 policy locking and workflow

Policy locking is available in workspace normal and per-ADOM modes. Policy locking allows administrators to work on, and lock, sing policy package instead of locking the whole ADOM. In order to use policy locking, you must set workspace-mode to normal. You can lock either the whole ADOM or a specific policy package.

So, this:
A) two or more administrators in the same ADOM (correct - policy locking)
B) does not prevent being in multiple ADOMS (correct)
C) Incorrect - Concurrent RW access to ADOM is disabled (policy locking allows this per ADOM)
D) Incorrect - obviously not an answer for this question. Nothing to do with authentication

Selected Answer: AB
7.4 study guide, pg 205 policy locking and workflow

ADOM revision history allows you to maintain a revision of the policy packages, objects, and VPN console settings in an ADOM.

Answer AB for my. Page 239 Study Guide

Policy locking is available in workspace normal mode only. Policy locking allows administrators to work on, and lock, a single policy package instead of locking the whole ADOM. In order to use policy locking, you must set workspace-mode to normal. You can lock either the whole ADOM or a specific policy package. Policy locking is an extension of ADOM locking, which allows multiple administrators to work on separate policy packages on the same ADOM at the same time.

choices.A: Two or more administrators can make configuration changes at the same time, in the same ADOM.
choices.B: The same administrator can lock more than one ADOM at the same time.
choices.D: You can validate administrator login attempts through external servers.
choices.C: Concurrent read-write access to an ADOM is disabled.
During discovery, FortiManager sets the NATed device IP address on FortiGate.
choices.A: During discovery, FortiManager uses only the FortiGate serial number to establish the connection.
choices.D: During discovery, FortiManager sets both the FortiManager NATed IP address and NAT device IP address on FortiGate.
choices.B: During discovery, FortiManager sets the FortiManager NATed IP address on FortiGate.

questions.question_text:
Refer to the exhibit.

//IMG//


An administrator is about to add the FortiGate device to FortiManager using the discovery process. FortiManager is operating behind a NAT device, and the administrator configured the FortiManager NATed IP address under the FortiManager system administration settings.

What is the expected result?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
B is correct - This setup ensures that FortiGate knows how to properly communicate with FortiManager through the NAT device.

Selected Answer: B
B is correct. 7.2 manual page 277

Selected Answer: B
The correct answer is B. During discovery, FortiManager sets the FortiManager NATed IP address on FortiGate.

When adding a FortiGate device to FortiManager using the discovery process, and FortiManager is operating behind a NAT device, configuring the FortiManager's NATed IP address in the system administration settings of FortiManager is crucial. This setup ensures that the FortiGate device can communicate with the FortiManager through the NAT device. By providing the NATed IP address of FortiManager, you're essentially telling the FortiGate where to send its management traffic so that it can be properly routed through the NAT device to reach the FortiManager.

The process does not involve setting the NAT device's IP address on the FortiGate; instead, it utilizes the configured NATed IP address of the FortiManager to establish the management connection. This makes option B the expected result of this configuration scenario.

Selected Answer: B
7.4 Study Guide, page 240
Noe: Same graphic on the slide

You can configure the FortiManger NATed IP address on FortiGate under the central management configuration. This allows FortiGate to announce itself to FortiManager and try to re-establish the FGFM tunnel, if it is torn down. Configuring the FortiManager NATed IP address on FortiGate allows both FortiManager and FortiGate to re-establish the FGFM tunnel. Also, if you configure the FortiManager NATed IP address under the FortiManager system administrator settings, FortiManager sets this address on FortiGate during the discovery process.

Selected Answer: C
during discovery the FMG will deploy the NATed IP on the managed FGT.
So, it should be C

comments.content: I am wrong. It is B

choices.B: It allows administrative access to FortiManager.
choices.A: It allows FortiManager to determine the connection status of managed devices.
choices.D: It allows FortiManager to respond to requests for FortiGuard services from FortiGate devices.
choices.C: It allows third-party applications to gain read/write access to FortiManager.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
D is Correct. 
Enabling Service Access on FortiManager can include settings that allow it to act as a proxy or intermediary for FortiGuard services to managed FortiGate devices. This is particularly useful in network architectures where direct communication from FortiGate devices to FortiGuard servers is restricted or not possible.

Selected Answer: D
FortiManager Study Guide for FortiManager 7.2
See Page 26

Selected Answer: D
D is correct Service access allows you to enable the FortiManager response to the requests from managed devices for
FortiGuard services on this interface. This includes FortiGate updates and web filtering. By default, all
services to managed devices are enabled on port1 and disabled on other ports. 

manual page 26

Selected Answer: D
The purpose of Service Access on the FortiManager interface is D. It allows FortiManager to respond to requests for FortiGuard services from FortiGate devices.

When Service Access is enabled on a FortiManager interface, it allows the interface to act as a proxy or distribution point for FortiGuard services to the FortiGate devices managed by the FortiManager. This setup is particularly useful in scenarios where direct internet access from all FortiGate devices is restricted or undesirable. By configuring FortiManager to handle FortiGuard requests, administrators can centralize the update process for security services (such as antivirus updates, IPS updates, and URL filtering databases) and ensure that managed devices are consistently protected with the latest security content without needing direct internet access from each device.

Selected Answer: D
D is correct.
Select the Fortinet services that are allowed access on this interface. These include FortiGate Updates and Web Filtering. Service access is not enabled on any port by default.

https://docs.fortinet.com/document/fortimanager/7.2.4/administration-guide/578841/configuring-network-interfaces

questions.question_text:
An administrator has enabled Service Access on FortiManager.

What is the purpose of Service Access on the FortiManager interface?

choices.D: That the NAT device IP address and correct ports are configured on FortiManager
choices.A: That the virtual IP address and correct ports are set on the NAT device
choices.B: That the override server IP address is set on FortiManager and the NAT device
choices.C: That the external IP address on the NAT device is set to DHCP and configured with the virtual IP

questions.question_text:
Push updates are failing on a FortiGate device that is located behind a NAT device.

Which two settings should the administrator check? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AD
ignore my previous answer, correct answer is A and D

Selected Answer: AB
Since the questions says fortigate then the answer is AB, but if the question regards fortimanager then the answers should be AD
It should be FortiManager, not FortiGate, right?

Selected Answer: AD
A - Correct you can not forward traffic if you do not configure the proper virtual IP and port details on the nat device
B - wrong it seems that that override is configured to fortigates only. https://community.fortinet.com/t5/FortiGate/Technical-Tip-Enabling-Push-Updates-through-a-NAT-device/ta-p/197050
C - wrong you can not use dhcp manual 7.2 page 349
D - correct check manul page 349
